thread.title: Lewis Hamilton: Four races left so United States Grand Prix is not do-or-die
thread.title_full: Lewis Hamilton: Four races left so United States Grand Prix is not do-or-die

title: Lewis Hamilton: Four races left so United States Grand Prix is not do-or-die
text:
Lewis Hamilton: Four races left so United States Grand Prix is not do-or-die 25 Oct 2015 17:01:52 
comments 
Lewis Hamilton has said Sunday's United States Grand Prix is not "do-or-die" even though a victory in Austin would see the Briton crowned Formula One champion. 
Hamilton needs to outscore Sebastian Vettel and Nico Rosberg by nine and two points respectively to seal his third world title later on Sunday. 
But, after Rosberg secured his third straight pole position in Sunday morning's rescheduled qualifying session, Hamilton, who starts second, insists he will not take any risks in the bad weather which has plagued the weekend's action. 
"Qualifying is just the beginning and the race is obviously a long battle," said Hamilton, who is now on a four-race streak without pole. "It is going to be hard out there today in those conditions varying throughout the race. 
"I think it is about being sensible and caring. I don't need to take any particular risks. There are four races left so it is not do-or-die this weekend." 
Twenty hours later than billed, qualifying started at 0900 on Sunday even though it was difficult to see how conditions had greatly improved. 
Indeed the torrential rain, which has battered the Texas region since Friday, worsened throughout the one-hour session and the top-10 shootout to determine the grid was eventually abandoned. 
The times from Q2 were taken to determine the grid with Rosberg on pole ahead of Hamilton and Red Bull's Daniel Ricciardo in third. Vettel qualified fifth but the Ferrari driver will be demoted 10 further places after an engine change. 
It appears Hamilton's only rival to him winning a third championship in America is Rosberg. 
"It was supposed to be drying out but it does not look like it out there so who knows?" said Rosberg, who started here on pole last year but was overtaken by Hamilton during the race. 
"I feel good in any condition at the moment and our car is great in any condition so whatever it is it will be fine." Related Sport News
